section.title: Creating Deployment Scripts
section.para: The first step is to create common deployment scripts that can be used across installation and update test sessions.

The CentOS Studio model for automated deployment is simple, yet flexible and and extensible. Repositories can be deployed in a variety of operating environments, for example using virtual machines running on a local host, virtual machines running on remote or cloud-based hosts, or physical machines managed by enterprise systems management systems.

To accomplish this flexibility, CentOS Studio allows users to provide scripts for completing various deployment and maintenance actions. These scripts can be written in any shell scripting language. By default, CentOS Studio executes some scripts on the local build machine and others on the client machine using Secure Shell (SSH).

When CentOS Studio executes a script using SSH, it first copies it to the client machine using Secure Copy (SCP). After copying, it then executes the script using SSH as the root user. CentOS Studio leaves copied scripts on the remote machine to assist with troubleshooting. They can be located in the /var/lib/centosstudio folder. For information on other files CentOS Studio copies to the /root/sysconfig/centosstudio folder, see the element. See also the CentOS Studio User Manual for more information on testing and troubleshooting solution installation and updates.
CentOS Studio supports password authentication for SSH connections. It does not support public key or host-based authentication.

Users can disable CentOS Studio's built in SSH execution for any script. This allows users to provide support for remote connections and authentication using any method desired directly within the user-provided script.
